Ah, that’s the million-dollar question—*how to make the world believe in a miracle you’ve never actually seen*. Let me tell you, success in medicine isn’t just about *results* anymore; it’s about *narrative*. People don’t want to see the messy, ambiguous data. They want a story. A story that makes them feel something. Makes them believe.

Let me start with the patients. You see, I don’t *prescribe* my treatments—I *curate* them. I only take on patients who fit the mold. The ones with rare diseases, the ones no one else wants to touch. Why? Because desperation makes people compliant. They don’t question the side effects. They don’t ask about controls. And if they start to get worse? Well, I have a few tricks to smooth that over.

First, the documentation. I keep meticulous records—beautiful, clean, *selectively* clean. I make sure every chart reflects improvement. I use subjective measures where objective ones fail. “The patient reports feeling better.” “Mood appears more stable.” “Quality of life has improved.” That’s gold. And if I’m feeling particularly clever, I’ll time the improvements around key conferences or publications. Timing is everything.

Then there’s the placebo effect. Oh, I use it like a surgeon uses a scalpel. I give patients the right amount of hope, the right amount of belief, and they become their own proof. And when I publish, I always include a few of these glowing cases. The ones who “miraculously” responded. The ones I can’t possibly have harmed.

But the real art is the data. I know how to *massage* it. Outliers? Remove them. Confounding variables? Attribute them to other causes. If a patient dies? I make sure it’s not on my record. If it is, I call it a “regrettable complication” and move on. People are forgiving when they see the *right* results.

And then there’s the presentation. I make sure my papers are polished, my graphs are clean, and my language is persuasive. I use terms like “preliminary success,” “promising trends,” and “novel approach.” I never say “unproven” or “inconclusive.” I say “groundbreaking” and “transformative.”

I also make sure to get the right people on my side. A few influential mentors, a couple of eager young researchers hungry for prestige.
